start.title:
Road to Renaissance

Leonardo’s Journey with Similar Triangles
start.description: Florence, 1470s. A young Leonardo da Vinci seeks out the great scholar Toscanelli, determined to unlock the mathematical secrets hidden within art and nature. In this STEAMQuest, you’ll join Leonardo’s apprenticeship and explore the timeless geometry that helped shape the Renaissance and the modern world.

S2_D1_F4_C0.heading: Welcome to Florence!
S2_D1_F4_C0.body: I’m Paolo dal Pozzo Toscanelli. Today, I’ll be guiding young Leonardo da Vinci, and you, through the hidden power of similar triangles. Together, we’ll explore how the ancients used them to measure the height of pyramids, prove the Pythagorean Theorem, and unlock the secrets of light and vision through the camera obscura.

S3.S3_D1_FX_C2: Master Toscanelli? I’m Leonardo da Vinci. My teacher says I must learn geometry… but to be honest, I don’t know why I need to learn about shapes and lines.
S3.S3_D2_FX_C1: Geometry isn’t just shapes and lines, it’s the structure behind everything. It’s how we understand how trees grow, how shadows fall, how buildings stand, how light moves. It’s the hidden design beneath nature, art, and vision.
S3.S3_D3_FX_C2: All that... from geometry?
S3.S3_D4_FX_C1: Yes. The ancients used it to measure pyramids, to prove the Pythagorean Theorem, and to explain how light forms images. It's a way of seeing the world more clearly and more deeply.
S3.S3_D5_FX_C2: I had no idea it reached so far. I want to understand all of it.

S4.S4_D1_FX_C1: The year was 600 BCE. A Greek philosopher named Thales of Miletus stood before the Great Pyramid of Giza.
S4.S4_D2_FX_C1: The Pharaoh’s officials challenged him to measure the height of the pyramid without climbing it.
S4.S4_D3_FX_C2: Measure something so massive without touching it? How could he possibly do that?
S4.S4_D4_FX_C1: He used similar triangles. Let’s see how he did this.

about.heading: Understanding the Math Behind Thales' Shadow Method
about.body:
In this interactive, you will explore how the ancient mathematician Thales used shadows and similar triangles to measure the height of the Great Pyramid without climbing it.

When the sun shines, a stick and the pyramid both create right triangles with their shadows. Because the sun’s rays hit both objects at the same angle, the triangles are similar, meaning their side ratios are equal.

hsticksstick=hpyramidspyramid
The fraction of height of stick divided by shadow of stick equals the fraction of height of pyramid divided by shadow of pyramid

Where, hstick = height of the stick that Thales used, sstick = the length of the stick’s shadow, spyramid = the length of the pyramid’s shadow and hpyramid = height of pyramid.

How does it work?

As both the objects are in the same sunlight, the triangles formed are similar, the ratios stay the same, even though the stick and pyramid are different sizes!

help.heading: How to calculate the height of the Pyramid?
help.body:
Hint: Follow these steps:

  1. Set the measuring stick height slider.
  2. Set the time slider.
  3. Observe the shadows and similar triangles formed by the Sun.
  4. Use this formula to calculate the height of Pyramid:
stick heightstick shadow=pyramid heightpyramid shadow
stick height divided by stick shadow equals pyramid height divided by pyramid shadow

thales.noonWarning: At noon, the sun is directly overhead and objects cast no shadows, making the shadow method calculation impossible.

thales.formula_1: h stick divided by s stick equals h pyramid divided by s pyramid.

S5.S5_D1_FX_C1: Picture Thales standing beside the pyramid, with no ropes and no ladders. Just a vertical stick and the sun above.
S5.S5_D2_FX_C2: So he didn’t measure the pyramid directly?
S5.S5_D3_FX_C1: No. He measured something easier, the height and shadow length of a stick, and the shadow length of the pyramid. That’s all he needed.
S5.S5_D4_FX_C1: The sun’s rays hit both the stick and the pyramid at the same angle. That created two similar right triangles, same shape but different sizes.
S5.S5_D5_FX_C1: And with similar triangles, the sides are in proportion. That’s the key.
S5.S5_D6_FX_C1: The stick’s height compared to its shadow is the same ratio as the pyramid’s height to its shadow.
S5.S5_D8_FX_C2:
So that means: stick height divided by stick shadow is equals to pyramid height divided by pyramid shadow

S5.S5_D9_FX_C1: Perfect. We can use this equation to solve for the pyramid’s unknown height.
S5.S5_D10_FX_C1: Set the time to 10:00 AM and stick height to 4.60 feet. Observe the shadows and the similar triangles formed by the sun at 10:00 AM.
S5.S5_D11_FX_C1: What is the estimated height of the pyramid (in feet)?
S5.S5_D12_FX_C1: Correct! The actual height of the pyramid is 482 feet, so it is very close to Thales’s approximation.
S5.S5_D13_FX_C2: Incredible. With just one stick, a shadow, and a ratio, he calculated the height of one of the greatest structures in the world.
S5.S5_D14_FX_C1: That’s the brilliance of proportional reasoning. When you understand relationships, you don’t always need to measure the thing itself.

S6_D0_FX_C9.title: Proving Pythagoras with Similar Triangles

about.heading: Understanding the Math Behind Proving Pythagoras with Similar Triangles
about.body:
This interactive shows how the Pythagorean Theorem

CB² + AC² = AB²
CB squared plus AC squared equals A B squared can be proved using similar triangles.

Steps to prove Pythagoras Theorem using similar triangles:

  • Observe how an altitude is drawn from the right angle to the hypotenuse, dividing the triangle into two smaller right triangles
  • Use the similarity of triangles to set up proportions and derive two equations
  • Add the equations to arrive at the final result

S6.S6_D1_FX_C1: Measuring shadows to find heights was just the beginning. Soon after Thales, another thinker explored the triangle itself.
S6.S6_D2_FX_C1: In southern Italy, a philosopher named Pythagoras discovered something remarkable about right triangles.
S6.S6_D3_FX_C2: Pythagoras? The one who said that in right triangles, the square of the length of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides.
S6.S6_D4_FX_C1: Yes. Fill the blank spaces by dragging and dropping sides into the blanks and complete the formula of Pythagorean Theorem.
S6.S6_D5_FX_C1: Correct! But his proof didn’t use squares alone, it used similar triangles.
S6.S6_D6_FX_C1: Let me show you how he revealed one of the most powerful truths in geometry.
S6.S6_D7_FX_C1: See this is triangle △Triangle ACB, where angle C is a right angle. If we draw an altitude from point C to the hypotenuse AB, meeting it at point D...
S6.S6_D8_FX_C2: The triangle is split into two smaller right triangles.
S6.S6_D9_FX_C1: Exactly. And since they all share the same angles, the three triangles are similar. That similarity is the key to proving Pythagorean Theorem. Let’s see how.
S6.S6_D10_FX_C1: Now look at our actual triangle △Triangle ACB, and the first smaller triangle △Triangle CDB.
S6.S6_D11_FX_C2: They share the same angles, so they must be similar.
S6.S6_D12_FX_C1: Yes. That means the ratios of one side and hypotenuse in both triangles are equal. Fill in the blank spaces with the sides of △Triangle CDB that correspond to the sides of △Triangle ACB.
S6.S6_D13_FX_C1:
Correct. Rearranging the terms in the ratios will give our first key equation: a² = cx.
a squared equals c multiplied by x
S6.S6_D14_FX_C1: The actual triangle △Triangle ACB and second smaller triangle △Triangle ADC...
S6.S6_D15_FX_C2: They also must be similar and because of that, the ratios of one side and hypotenuse in both triangles are equal.
S6.S6_D16_FX_C1: Yes! Fill in the blank spaces with the sides of △Triangle ADC that correspond to the sides of △Triangle ACB.
S6.S6_D17_FX_C1:
Correct! Here also if we rearrange the terms in the ratios it will give our second key equation: b² = c² - cx.
b squared equals c squared minus c multiplied by x
S6.S6_D18_FX_C1: Now we have two equations from our similar triangles. We need to add these two equations.
S6.S6_D19_FX_C2: If we add them, then the cxc multiplied by x terms cancel out and we get a² + b² = c².a squared plus b squared equals c squared
S6.S6_D20_FX_C1:
Exactly! If we write it in another way then:
CB² + AC² = AB².
CB squared plus AC squared equals A B squared And that’s it Leonardo, the Pythagorean Theorem is proved with similar triangles.

S7.S7_D1_FX_C1: After Pythagoras, geometry continued to unlock even bigger questions.
S7.S7_D2_FX_C2: Bigger questions? What could geometry solve beyond triangles?
S7.S7_D3_FX_C1: Much more. Around 240 BCE, in Alexandria, a librarian named Eratosthenes used geometry to measure the Earth itself.
S7.S7_D4_FX_C2: He measured the whole planet? Without ever leaving Egypt?
S7.S7_D5_FX_C1: Yes. He used careful shadows, angles, and proportions to estimate the size of the Earth. Let’s take a look at how he did this.

S8_D0_FX_C9.title: Earth Circumference Calculator

about.heading: Understanding the Math Behind Eratosthenes' Measurement of Earth's Circumference
about.body:
In this interactive, you will explore how Eratosthenes estimated the circumference of the Earth over 2,000 years ago using shadows, angles, and proportions.

On June 21st (the summer solstice), at exactly 12:00 PM, the sun was directly overhead in Syene (modern-day Aswan, Egypt). At that moment, sunlight reached the bottom of a deep well, casting no shadow. Meanwhile, in Alexandria, a vertical stick did cast a shadow. Eratosthenes measured the angle between the stick and the sun’s rays in Alexandria was about 7.2 degrees.

Because the sun’s rays are nearly parallel, the angle between the stick and the sun in Alexandria is the same as the central angle between Alexandria and Syene at the center of the Earth. The measured 7.2° angle is 1/50th of a full circle (since

7.2°360°=150
7.2 degrees divided by 360 degrees equals 1 divided 50.).

He set up the following proportion:

Angle at Alexandria360°=Distance between Alexandria and SyeneEarth's Circumference
Angle at Alexandria divided by 360 degrees equals Distance between Alexandria and Syene divided by Earth's Circumference.

Where, Angle at Alexandria = measured shadow angle (about 7.2°), 360° = total degrees in a full circle and, Distance between Alexandria and Syene = 500 miles.

help.heading: How to calculate the Earth’s circumference?
help.body:
Follow these steps:

  1. Set the screen distance slider.
  2. Use this formula to calculate the Earth’s circumference:
7.2°360°=500 milesEarth's Circumference
7.2 degrees divided by 360 degrees equals 500 miles divided by Earth's Circumference.

S8_D0_FX_C9.formula_2: 7.2 degrees divided by 360 degrees equals 500 miles divided by Earth's Circumference. Earth's Circumference equals 25 thousand miles.

S8.S8_D6_FX_C1: At noon on June 21st, in Syene, the sun is directly overhead. It shines straight into a well, so there is no shadow at all.
S8.S8_D7_FX_C2: But in Alexandria, the stick does cast a shadow! So the sun isn’t directly above here?
S8.S8_D7_FX_C1: Yes. That small shadow tells us the sun is hitting Earth at a slightly different angle, because Earth is curved.
S8.S8_D8_FX_C1: Eratosthenes measured the angle of the shadow, it was about 7.2°.
S8.S8_D8_F1_C1: Since 360 degrees is a full circle, how much is 7.2 degrees?

S8.S8_D14_FX_C2: It's incredible... using shadows and clever thinking to measure the whole world!

S9.S9_D1_FX_C1: Centuries after Eratosthenes, another great mind turned to the mysteries of light and vision.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C2: Light and vision? Who was it?
S9.S9_D3_FX_C1: In Baghdad, around the year 1000, a scientist named Ibn al-Haytham began studying how we see the world.
S9.S9_D4_FX_C2: He explored vision using geometry too?
S9.S9_D5_FX_C1: Yes. He used the setup known as camera obscura and the idea of similar triangles to understand how light forms images, leading to discoveries that changed both science and art forever.

S10_D0_FX_C9.title: Camera Obscura Simulator

about.heading: Understanding the Math Behind the Camera Obscura
about.body:
In this interactive, you will explore how a camera obscura works, an ancient device that shows how light creates an inverted image through a small opening.

When light rays from an object (like the Florence Cathedral) pass through a tiny pinhole into a dark room, they form an upside-down image on a screen. The light travels in straight lines and forms similar triangles between the object, the pinhole, and the projected image.

The relationship between the object, the pinhole, and the image can be described with this proportion:

Image HeightObject Height=Screen DistanceObject Distance
Image Height divided by Object Height equals Screen Distance divided by Object Distance.

Where, Image Height = height of the inverted image on the screen, Object Height = height of the original object (like the cathedral), Screen Distance = distance from the pinhole to the screen and Object Distance = distance from the pinhole to the object.

How does it work?

  • Light forms similar triangles between the object and the screen
  • As the screen distance increases, the image height increases, keeping the same proportions
  • The inverted image is a natural result of the way light rays cross after passing through the pinhole

By understanding these proportions, you can predict how large or small the projected image will be based on where you place the screen!

help.heading: How to calculate image height?
help.body:
Hint follow these steps:

  • Adjust the screen distance slider.
  • Observe the similar triangles.
  • Use this formula to calculate image height:
Image HeightObject Height=Screen DistanceObject Distance
Image height divided by Object height equals Screen Distance divided by Object Distance.

S10.S10_D4_FX_C1: Yes. Light travels in straight lines. When it passes through a small opening, it crosses over and projects the image upside down.
S10.S10_D5_FX_C1: The object, the pinhole, and the image form two similar triangles.
S10.S10_D6_FX_C2: Similar triangles again? So the proportions match?

S10.S10_D8_FX_C1: If the object height is 394 ft, the object distance is 15 ft, and the screen distance is 5 ft, what is the image height?
S10.S10_D10_FX_C1: Correct! Now, increase the screen distance. Move the screen farther away from the pinhole.
S10.S10_D12_FX_C1: Exactly. As the screen moves farther away, the image grows taller. The triangles stay similar, but their size increases with distance.
S10.S10_D13_FX_C1: Now, if the object distance is 10 ft, and the screen distance is also 10 ft, what will the new image height be?
S10.S10_D14_FX_C1: Correct! The image height matches the object height when the distances are equal.
S10.S10_D15_FX_C2: So by using just light and geometry, we can predict how large an image will be!
S10.S10_D16_FX_C1: Yes. This understanding changed how we studied vision and light and even how artists designed their paintings.

S11.S11_D1_FX_C1: You have walked in the footsteps of giants: Thales, Pythagoras, Eratosthenes, Ibn al-Haytham. They measured shadows, calculated the Earth, and captured light, all using triangles. Geometry does not just describe the world, it reveals it. Proportion is the thread that weaves nature, art, and truth together.
S11.S11_D2_FX_C2: I thought it was just lines and shapes, but it is the invisible made visible in the fall of light, the sweep of shadows, and even in how vision works
S11.S11_D3_FX_C1: Good. Take it and use it. Let geometry guide your brush, your inventions, and your questions. Let it shape the way you see.
S11.S11_D4_FX_C2: It already has. My journey has begun, and I will never look at the world the same way again.

quest_completion.subheading: You Explored How Similar Triangles Shaped Art, Science, and Discovery
quest_completion.content:
You've completed the Road to Renaissance: Leonardo's Journey STEAMQuest!

  • You discovered how Thales measured the height of a pyramid using shadows and similar triangles
  • You learned how to prove the Pythagorean Theorem using similar triangles
  • You explored how Eratosthenes estimated Earth's circumference through geometry and observation
  • You learned how Ibn al-Haytham explained vision and light behavior with similar triangles and the camera obscura

Your understanding of similar triangles will help you see the hidden geometry in the world around you, just like Leonardo da Vinci did!
quest_completion.leftsvgarialabel: Geometric diamond shape icon representing mathematics and measurement.

camera_obscura.definition: Camera obscura is a dark room or box with a small hole on one side. Light passes through the hole and projects an inverted image of the outside scene onto the screen or opposite wall. This ancient optical device helped scientists understand how light travels and was a key step in the invention of modern cameras.

summer_solstice.definition: Summer solstice is the longest day of the year, when the sun is highest in the sky. It happens around June 21st in the Northern Hemisphere.

similar_triangles.definition: Similar triangles are triangles that have the same angles and equal side ratios.

proportions.definition: Proportion is a relationship where two ratios are equal.

right_triangle.definition: Right triangle is a triangle that has one 90-degree angle.

right_triangles.definition: Right triangles are triangles that have one 90-degree angle.

altitude.definition: Altitude of a triangle is a line segment that is drawn from the vertex of a triangle to the side opposite to it. It is perpendicular to the base or the opposite side which it touches.

hypotenuse.definition: Hypotenuse is the longest side of a right triangle, always opposite the right angle.

circumference.definition: Circumference is the total distance around a circle.

pythagorean_theorem.definition: Pythagorean Theorem is a rule in math says that in a right triangle, the square of the longest side (called the hypotenuse) is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
